I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The country strategy and program of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for Solomon 
Islands aims to contribute to rapid, pro-poor, and private sector-led economic growth. It foresees 
support  to  the  Government  by  providing  transportation  infrastructure  and  services  and 
strengthening the enabling environment for the private sector. Private sector participation in, 
and reform of, the state-owned enterprise (SOE) sector are high-priority areas, in which ADB 
has had a history of support to Solomon Islands. The Government has recognized the vital role 
the private sector must play in the rehabilitation of the economy. The economic rehabilitation 
and development process led by the Regional Assistance Mission to the Solomon Islands 
(RAMSI) is providing a unique window of opportunity for public and private sector reforms.  
 
2.  During ADB's 2004 Country Programming Mission, which coincided with the TA Fact- 
Finding Mission, it was agreed with the Government that ADB will provide technical assistance 
(TA) in support of developing and implementing privatization policies and reforms, private sector 
participation, and SOE performance improvement.1 The Government concurs with the TA's 
goal, purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms 
of reference. The TA framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  As part of the 1998 Public Sector Reform Program in Solomon Islands, ADB provided a 
TA loan to support implementation of the Government’s privatization policy.2 The TA loan was 
designed to help privatize selected SOEs, improve the financial performance of SOEs that 
would  remain  under  government  ownership,  and  develop  appropriate  legal  and  regulatory 
frameworks for those sectors in which the privatized SOEs would operate. While the TA loan 
was generally regarded as successful during its implementation, the 2000 coup d'etat resulted 
in the cancellation of the project and made its outputs obsolete. However, RAMSI, fielded in 
June 2003, has helped the Government restore law and order and fiscal discipline, and  embark 
on  the  national  economic  recovery,  reform,  and  development  program.  The  country's 
development  partners  are  strongly  supportive  of  the  process,  and  ADB  has  taken  on  a 
substantial role in the focus areas of its assistance.  
 
4.   Economic reforms to address major constraints on the sustainable growth of private 
sector income-earning opportunities have been an important pillar of the RAMSI-led process. A 
number of key strategies include SOE reforms and privatization, development of transport 
infrastructure and utilities, private sector regulatory reforms, financial sector reforms, provision 
of policy and governance advice to provincial governments, and formulation of sectoral policies 
to promote investment and growth, among others. To assist in formulating and implementing 
economic reforms, an Economic Reform Unit (ERU) was established within the Ministry of 
Finance, National Reform and Planning. ADB's country strategy and program is geared toward 
supporting  ERU's  operations  in  cooperation  with  other  sources,  especially  in  the  areas  of 
privatization and SOE reforms, infrastructure policy and regulation, and legal and regulatory 
business environment. 
 
5.  Solomon Islands has 17 SOEs, including statutory authorities; air transport services; 
telecoms (with a recently renewed 15-year monopoly concession); resource-based enterprises

2  
in forestry, fishing, and agricultural production; and service providers in areas such as ship 
repair  and  maintenance,  printing,  tourism  promotion,  and  export  marketing.  Weak  SOE 
management combined with ineffective SOE corporate governance regimes has resulted in 
poor service delivery and financial performance, posing a heavy burden on public finances, 
businesses and consumers alike. The Investment Corporation of Solomon Islands (ICSI), which 
is the management and oversight authority for some of the SOEs, has not been in a position to 
fulfill its mandate effectively. Generally, corporate governance standards have not worked well 
in the country’s SOE sector and, with few exceptions, the technical, commercial, and financial 
SOE performance has been deteriorating over the last decade.  
 
6.  While it is recognized that the per unit cost of producing public goods on a relatively 
small  scale  is  high,  the  experience  of  Solomon  Islands  as  well  as  internationally  strongly 
suggests  that  governments  and  inadequately  regulated  monopolies  produce  services  at 
unnecessarily high costs and usually of low quality. Considering its unsuccessful history in 
providing basic utilities, infrastructure, and commercial services, the Government has decided to 
focus more on its core purposes by reducing, to the extent possible and feasible, its involvement 
in commercial activities and those activities that can more effectively and efficiently be provided 
by the private sector.  
 
7.  Reform of the SOEs will need to consider various options for improving performance, 
including better management, corporatization, and privatization within an appropriate regulatory 
framework. Appropriate regulation and management of SOEs are essential to improve the 
quality of service and to run operations in a sustainable manner. Consideration should be given 
to introducing private sector participation and competition in hitherto public (and semiprivate) 
monopolies.  It  is  important  to  base  SOE-specific  decisions  on  a  sound  policy  on  SOE 
ownership, performance, and divestment, as well as on effective regulatory frameworks.  
 
8.  The TA will support ERU in building on  progress made during the privatization exercises 
associated  with  the  1998  Public  Sector  Reform  Program,  and  strengthening  government 
capacity to implement SOE reforms. It will be closely coordinated with activities under the 
second ADB country assistance focus area—transportation infrastructure and services—as well 
as with relevant activities of other aid agencies. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The goal of the TA is to support the Government in its efforts to improve the environment 
for the private sector, in line with the strategic focus of ADB's country strategy and program for 
Solomon  Islands.  The  purpose  is  to  assist  the  Government  to  improve  SOE  ownership 
arrangements, accountability, and performance. The TA outputs are (i) a sound government 
policy  on  SOE  ownership,  performance,  and  divestment;  (ii)  private  sector  participation  in 
prioritized SOEs (including full privatization); (iii) adequate legal and regulatory frameworks for 
those sectors in which privatized SOEs will operate; (iv) reporting and performance monitoring 
regime for SOEs that will remain under State ownership; and (v) on-the-job training for key 
stakeholders in government and SOEs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will have four interlinked components: (i) SOE ownership policy, strategy, and 
legal and regulatory frameworks; (ii) privatization (including private sector participation); (iii)

3
SOE  reporting  and  performance  monitoring  regime;  and  (iv)  capacity  building  for  local 
counterparts at ERU, relevant ministries, and SOEs.  
 
11.  TA activities under each component will be closely aligned with ERU's work program and 
staff capacities. The TA will include, but will not be limited to, the following key activities:  
 
(i)  Analyze the status quo of the SOE portfolio, including the current reporting and 
monitoring regime. 
(ii)  Develop an effective SOE ownership and performance policy and a privatization 
road  map,  and  achieve  reform  ownership  through  an  intensive  high-level 
consultation process. 
(iii)  Review the role of ICSI, and recommend longer-term institutional arrangements 
for SOE oversight and monitoring. 
(iv)  Develop and implement regulatory frameworks for sectors in which privatized 
SOEs operate. 
(v)  Implement the privatization of selected SOEs. 
(vi)  Develop and implement systems and measures to improve accountability and 
performance of SOEs remaining in public ownership 
(vii)  Develop  and  introduce  appropriate  systems  and  guidelines  for  managing 
community service obligations. 
(viii)  Improve SOE board composition and appointments. 
(ix)  Conduct  on-the-job  training  in  privatization  and  SOE  management  for 
government officials and SOE staff. 
(x)  Lead  a  comprehensive  consultation  process;  develop  and  implement  public 
information campaigns on the need for service delivery reforms. 
 
12.  The TA will take into consideration the Government's broader development and sector 
priorities,  Government  and  SOEs  capacity  constraints,  and  political  realities,  and  will 
complement other relevant aid activities with respect to SOE reforms. In particular, TA activities 
will be coordinated with closely related World Bank-assisted TAs for reform and regulation of 
infrastructure utilities. While World Bank assistance will focus on SOE internal reforms, the ADB 
TA  will  provide  perspective  for  the  more  strategic  and  policy-oriented  SOE  portfolio 
management. The TA will also complement a separate ADB TA for interisland transportation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000 equivalent, comprising $684,000 in 
foreign  exchange  and  $316,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  ADB  will  provide  $800,000 
equivalent to finance the entire foreign exchange cost and $116,000 equivalent of the local 
currency cost on a grant basis, of which $300,000 will be financed by ADB's TA funding 
program  and  $500,000  by  the  Government  of  Australia,  to  be  administered  by  ADB.  The 
Government of Solomon Islands will finance the remaining $200,000 equivalent of the local 
currency costs for counterpart staff salaries, office accommodation at ERU, support services, 
and transport. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Department of Finance and Treasury of the Ministry of Finance, National Reform 
and Planning will be the Executing Agency. The permanent secretary of Finance will provide 
overall guidance in TA implementation. The consultants will work on a day-to-day basis with 
ERU and individual SOEs, as required. ERU will help facilitate consultations with SOEs. A

4  
steering committee will be established to help build consensus and drive the reform process. 
The  steering  committee  will  be  headed  by  the  permanent  secretary  of  the  Department  of 
Finance  and  Treasury,  and  members  include  senior  officials  from  relevant  government 
departments, selected SOEs, and representatives of the private sector and civil society.  
 
15.  Through  a  consulting  firm,  consulting  services  (24  person-months  international,  18 
person-months domestic) will be engaged using the simplified technical proposal following the 
quality- and cost-based selection procedures. The international consultant team will consist of a 
privatization specialist (team leader, 9 person-months), a corporate governance and financial 
specialist (8 person-months), and legal and regulatory experts specializing in transactions and 
regulatory  frameworks  (7  person-months  total).  The  international  consultant  team  will  be 
complemented by domestic financial and legal experts on an as-needed basis (18 person-
months total). The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The team of 
consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. 
 
16.  The TA will begin in March 2005 and be implemented over 24 months until February 
2007, with intermittent inputs from the international and domestic consultants. Within 4 weeks of  
the fielding of consultants, the team leader will submit an inception report to be discussed during 
a tripartite meeting with the Government and ADB. Progress reports will be submitted to ADB 
and the Government on a quarterly basis and detailed progress reports semiannually. Brief 
mission reports will be submitted (by E-mail) after each consultant field visit. A midterm report 
will be discussed during a second tripartite meeting. The Consultant’s draft final report will be 
discussed during the third tripartite meeting. The final report, incorporating the comments of  the 
Government and ADB, will be submitted within 4 weeks of the third tripartite meeting. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia, and (ii) ADB providing the balance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of Solomon 
Islands  for  State-Owned  Enterprise  Reforms  and  Private  Sector  Participation,  and  hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  International (24 person-months) and domestic (18 person-months) consultants will be 
engaged for the technical assistance (TA). 
 
A.  International Consultants (total 24.0 person-months) 
1.  Privatization Specialist Team Leader (9.0 person-months) 
 
2.  The privatization specialist must have a master’s degree in business administration, law, 
or a related field, and a minimum of 15 years of relevant work experience in areas related to the 
management of privatization processes. The consultant must have experience in working and 
guiding teams and building capacity, and have excellent communication skills. Privatization-
related work experience in the Pacific region or other small states is highly desirable.  
 
3.  The consultant will undertake the following specific tasks: 
 
(i)  Analyze  the  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE)  reform  environment,  including 
historical context and current situation with respect to the Economic Reform Unit 
(ERU), the Investment Corporation of the Solomon Islands (ICSI), other relevant 
government offices and agencies, and previous reform exercises such as the 
1998 privatization project by the Asian Development Bank (ADB); government 
policies and priorities for reform of SOEs as well as related public sector reforms, 
as appropriate; and the relevant legislative and regulatory framework, including 
SOEs’ respective statutes and legislation. 
 
(ii)  Together with the corporate governance and financial specialist, analyze the 
wider SOE environment, with particular attention to the financial reporting of 
Government  units  in  general  and  SOEs  in  particular;  legislative  issues;  and 
public accountability with reference to international best practice on governance, 
the roles of the relevant ministers, Parliamentary committees, and the media in 
the context of SOE governance and performance.  
 
(iii)  Together  with  the  corporate  governance  and  financial  specialist,  assess  the 
financial situations of all SOEs including financial management issues. Review 
the latest financial statements for accuracy and consistency. Analyze financial 
statements and discuss results with SOE management. Review previous audit 
reports and status of audit adjusting entries. Review SOEs' impact on public 
finances. For each SOE, clarify and confirm the Government’s management and 
policy objectives and reform strategy, if any.  
 
(iv)  Together with the corporate governance and financial specialist, develop an SOE 
ownership and performance policy, in close cooperation with all stakeholders 
concerned,  and  secure  political  ownership  of  such  policy.  On  that  basis, 
formulate  a  privatization  (including  private  sector  participation)  road  map, 
including  an  implementation  plan.  Give  special  consideration  to  the 
establishment of adequate regulatory frameworks for sectors in which privatized 
SOEs will operate. Coordinate with any other aid-assisted activities focusing on 
SOEs that may be relevant to the objectives and scope of the TA.

10  Appendix 3 
(v)  Together with the corporate governance and financial specialist, review the role 
of ICSI and recommend longer-term institutional arrangements for SOE oversight 
and monitoring. 
 
(vi)  Prepare  a  privatization  (private  sector  participation)  strategy  for  each  of  the 
targeted SOEs. Pay particular attention to assessing the privatization impact on 
the service delivery and financial performance of the particular SOE, as well as 
outstanding obligations including related legal issues. The corporate restructuring 
plans  should  include  an  assessment  of  relevant  labor  impact  and  issues  in 
enterprises, and a strategy and plan for labor restructuring, as appropriate. 
 
(vii)  Lead the policy dialogue with decision makers on the issue of privatization and 
private  sector  participation  and  develop  and  implement  a  public  information 
campaign targeting the wider public. 
 
(viii)  Provide hands-on assistance to ERU in implementing the approved privatization 
action plans. 
 
(ix)  Prepare a medium- to long-term action plan for each of the SOEs not privatized 
under  the  TA,  with  specific  focus  on  determining  a  second,  future  tier  of 
privatization and enhancing their performance if they remain in the public sector. 
Prepare an action plan for each SOE that will not be privatized in the foreseeable 
future, with a view to enhancing its service delivery and financial performance. 
 
(x)  Provide on-the-job training for ERU, relevant ministries, and SOEs related to the 
privatization and SOE reform process. 
 
(xi)  Assist  ERU  to  achieve  close  coordination  and  policy  dialogue  with  other 
government departments, SOEs, and the private sector. 
 
2.  Corporate Governance and Financial Specialist (8.0 person months) 
4.  The corporate governance and financial specialist must have an advanced degree in 
business administration, law, or other relevant discipline, and/or a professional designation in 
accountancy. The specialist will have a minimum of 10 years of work experience in financial 
analysis and corporate governance of public enterprises, and experience with privatization 
exercises,  preferably  in  developing  countries.  Practical  experience  with  management 
information  systems,  especially  as  they  relate  to  the  reporting  and  monitoring  of  public 
enterprises, is highly desirable. The consultant must have experience in working and guiding 
teams, and capacity building, and have excellent communication skills. Work experience in the 
Pacific region is desirable.  
 
5.  The  consultant  will  work  closely  together  with  the  team  leader  and  other  experts, 
complementing  the  team  capabilities  in  the  area  of  SOE  management,  reporting,  and 
monitoring. The consultant will undertake the following specific tasks: 
 
(i)  Together with the privatization specialist, analyze the wider SOE environment, 
with particular attention to the financial reporting of Government units in general 
and  SOEs  in  particular;  legislative  issues;  and  public  accountability  with 
reference to international best practice on governance, the roles of the relevant 
ministers,  Parliamentary  committees,  and  the  media  in  the  context  of  SOE

governance and performance. Assess the financial situations of all SOEs, as well 
as the financial management capacity1 of each SOE. Review the latest financial 
statements  for  accuracy  and  consistency.  Analyze  financial  statements  and 
discuss results with SOE management. Review previous audit reports and status 
of audit adjusting entries. Review SOEs' impact on public finances. For each 
SOE, clarify and confirm the Government’s management and policy objectives 
and reform strategy, if any.  
 
(ii)  In cooperation with the privatization specialist, develop an SOE ownership and 
performance  policy.  Formulate  a  privatization  (including  private  sector 
participation)  road  map,  including  implementation  plan.  Give  special 
consideration to the establishment of adequate regulatory frameworks for sectors 
in which privatized SOEs will operate. Coordinate with any other aid-assisted 
activities focusing on SOEs that may be relevant to the TA's objectives and 
scope. 
 
(iii)  Together with the privatization specialist, review the role of ICSI and recommend 
longer-term institutional arrangements for SOE oversight and monitoring. 
 
(iv)  Examine current accounting and reporting systems and procedures for all SOEs 
and  identify  problems  or  deficiencies.  Develop  and  achieve  consensus  on 
appropriate SOE reporting and monitoring procedures and mechanisms, and 
develop adequate guidelines, regulations, and legal changes, as required. Help 
the Government implement established accounting, reporting, and monitoring 
standards and systems in cooperation with SOEs. 
 
(v)  Develop and introduce appropriate systems and guidelines for the management 
of community service obligations. 
 
(vi)  Assist SOEs, as required, to implement and achieve compliance with reporting 
requirements, in the context of good change management principles. Assess 
SOE capacity-building needs to identify specific management capacity-building 
requirements for reporting and undertake appropriate action to address these. 
 
(vii)  Provide on-the-job training for local government counterpart staff involved in SOE 
monitoring. Prepare and deliver training courses, seminars, and workshops for 
SOE  financial  controllers  and  management  to  enable  them  to  satisfy  the 
reporting requirements of the SOE legislative framework, including but not limited 
to technical aspects of statutory and management reporting; and budgeting and 
financial forecasting, followed by provision of in-house assistance to SOEs in 
preparing their forecast budgets on request. 
 
(viii)  Review critical SOE governance systems and procedures including SOE board 
composition and appointment procedures. Make recommendations and achieve 
consensus.  Assist  the  Government  counterparts  to  implement  the 
recommendations, as appropriate.  
 
(ix)  Increase the capacity of SOEs to comply with the new reporting standards, and 
improve performance by conducting training courses, seminars, and workshops

3.  Legal and Regulatory Experts (1–2 person-months each, as necessary; total 
7.0 person-months) 
6.  The TA will also finance consultants to be involved on an as-needed basis, in (i) the 
development and implementation of regulatory frameworks for the sectors in which privatized 
SOEs will operate; and (ii) legal transactions support in the privatization exercises. The experts 
will have an advanced degree in law, economics, or in engineering, as appropriate. The experts 
will have wide-ranging experience in their respective fields, including in developing countries, 
preferably in the Pacific islands or other small states. 
 
7.  Regulatory framework consultants will work closely with ERU, Attorney General's Office, 
relevant ministries, and private sector representatives to draft appropriate regulations, policies, 
and/or legislation for sectors where privatized SOEs will operate. Specifically, the experts will 
perform the following activities: 
 
(i)  Evaluate the existing regulatory framework in the sector concerned. Assess the 
legal and legislative implications of the desired institutional arrangements for the 
sector.  
(ii)  Together with key stakeholders, identify legislative deficiencies and opportunities 
in current practices.  
(iii)  Recommend the appropriate legal and regulatory framework for the relevant 
sector to enable the country to achieve its goals and objectives in the sector 
concerned.  Indicate  the  legislative  process,  if  any,  that  may  be  required  to 
establish the required legal/regulatory framework.  
(iv)  In consultation with the sectoral ministries concerned, identify the process by 
which the required changes may be achieved and the likely timetable.  
(v)  Train relevant government staff on aspects related to the implementation of the 
proposed legal/regulatory framework. 
 
8.  The  legal  privatization  specialists  will  provide  transactions  assistance  to  both  the 
Government and SOEs, as and when required. The specialists will assist the Government in the 
transaction process when fully privatizing SOEs. In the case of other private sector participation 
options, the experts will assist SOEs in formulating and negotiating contracts with the private 
sector (e.g., service agreements, management contracts, management buyouts, concessions, 
etc.).  The experts will assist in preparing bid documents and procedures, and advise on the 
selection of operators.  
 
B.  Domestic Financial and Legal Experts (total 18.0 person-months) 
9.  Domestic financial and legal experts, sourced on an as-needed basis, will support the 
international consultant team and ERU. They will work together with the international team and 
ERU,  especially  in  the  financial  analysis  of  SOEs,2  impact  assessment  of  privatizations; 
implementation of privatization deals; implementation of SOE reporting and monitoring systems;

C.  Reporting Requirements 
10.  Within 4 weeks of the fielding of consultants, the team leader will submit an inception 
report to be discussed during a tripartite meeting with the Government and ADB. Progress 
reports  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  and  the  Government  on  a  quarterly  basis,  and  detailed 
progress reports semiannually. Brief mission reports will be submitted (by E-mail) after each 
consultant field visit. A midterm report will be discussed during the second tripartite meeting. 
The consultant’s draft final report will be discussed during the third tripartite meeting. The final 
report, incorporating the comments of the Government  and ADB, will be submitted to the 
Government and ADB within 4 weeks of the third tripartite meeting, in hard copy and CD ROM 
formats.
